Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-Australia Planning Visit: Geometrical Structure and Applications in the Symmetric Non-communtative Spaces of Measurable Operators
Award.AbstractNarration:
0943485
Kaminska

This award supports a planning visit to enable Professor Anna Kaminska at the University of Memphis in Tennessee to meet with Professor Fedor Sukochev at the University of New South Wales in Sydney, Australia and Professor Alan Carey at the Australian National University in Canberra. The visit will help develop a detailed international collaborative research project on isomorphic and isometric geometric properties of (quasi) Banach spaces. They will also include non-commutative operator theory in Hilbert spaces and non-commutative phenomena. The non-commutative spaces are generalization of the unitary ideals to the spaces of measurable operators affiliated to von Neumann algebra with trace, whose singular values lie in a symmetric Banach function space. In recent years they have become subjects of intense studies. During the visit in Sydney, the suggested research topics will be prioritized according to their importance, the degree of difficulties and their promises to be solved. The specific approach to each problem will be discussed and the work will be divided appropriately.

There is sufficient overlap of interests between faculty at the University of Memphis (with expertise in symmetric Banach function spaces), the University of New South Wales (with expertise in the non-commutative theory of measurable operators) and the Australian National University (with expertise in non-commutative geometry to indicate that they can successfully pursue the activities proposed, and that the interaction will benefit both sides. In addition, the involvement of a US graduate student from the University of Memphis will enable her to gain a valuable international perspective and insight. She will also participate in discussions on future collaborative activities with the researchers and will present her own research results at an Analysis Seminar at the South Wales University.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal investigator Anna Kaminska together with a Ph.D. student Malgorzata Czerwinska visited  the University of New South Wales in Australia in the period of March 1 - March 26 in 2010.
 
 During this visit there have been discussed several research topics jointly with Fedor Sukochev, a professor in the department of mathematics at that university and a leading specialist in the theory of noncommutative spaces of measurable operators. The topics included a number of problems on geometrical structure and applications in the symmetric noncommutative spaces. The investigations have been conducted  on  problems in isometric theory of these spaces, like complex strict and uniform rotundity, exposed and strongly exposed points, and smoothness properties. There were also discussed the Daugavet property and so called property (WM) introduced and studied earlier by  Kalton and Sukochev.   Besides that the studies on interpolation theory and its connection to noncommutative spaces have been initiated. Those research topics were prioritized according to their importance, the degree of difficulties and their promises to be solved.  The specific approach to each problem has been discussed and the work was divided appropriately.
 
 This visit appeared to be very fruitful and has had a big impact especially on research development  of Ms. Czerwinska. During the past year after returning from this trip,  three joint research papers on isometric properties in noncommutative spaces of measurable operators have been completed.  One of these papers has been already published and two others have been  accepted for publication in international mathematical journals.  There is further research collaboration pending with Fedor Sukochev.  Ms. Czerwinska defended  her Ph.D. thesis on geometric structure of the spaces of measurable operators. Her thesis was greatly influenced by the work performed in Australia within this project. She became seriously involved in the research in noncommutative analysis and her future as a research mathematician is very promising.

Traditionally women are underrepresented in mathematics, especially in the areas that require vast knowledge of abstract mathematics. The non-commutative theory of operators belongs to such area. Ms. Czerwinska with her talent and diligent work  has participated fully and equally in the work and discussions performed together with Fedor Sukochev.  It was very worthy to include her in this joint project. I expect her to become a conscious mathematician who in the future will fill the gender gap in advanced mathematics.

 


Last Modified: 05/05/2011
Modified by: Anna Kaminska
